headline: ConocoPhillips Stock Still Looks Cheap - What's The Best Play Here?
summary: ConocoPhillips reported strong cash flow and said it would pay out 45% of its operating cash flow to shareholders. That makes COP stock looks cheap. One way to play it is to sell short one-month puts with a yield of at least 2%.

raw.headline: ConocoPhillips Stock Still Looks Cheap - What's The Best Play Here?
raw.summary: ConocoPhillips reported strong cash flow and said it would pay out 45% of its operating cash flow to shareholders. That makes COP stock looks cheap. One way to play it is to sell short one-month puts with a yield of at least 2%.

headline: RBC Capital Maintains Hold Rating on Western Midstream (WES)
summary: Western Midstream Partners, LP (NYSE:WES) is one of the 11 Best Pipeline and MLP Stocks to Buy in 2026. RBC Capital’s Elvira Scotto reiterated the Hold rating on Western Midstream Partners, LP (NYSE:WES) and maintained a price target of $42 on January 28, 2026. In contrast, Morgan Stanley maintained its Sell rating on the stock. […]

headline: ConocoPhillips Q4 2025 net income drops 39% to $1.4bn
summary: The US-based company’s earnings decreased primarily due to lower prices, despite being partially offset by increased production volumes.

headline: ConocoPhillips Resets Spending After Weaker Earnings As 2026 Outlook Clarifies
summary: ConocoPhillips (NYSE:COP) reported weaker fourth quarter and full year earnings, alongside updated production guidance for 2026. The company outlined a plan to cut capital and operating costs by US$1b as part of a broader reset of its spending profile. Management highlighted progress on portfolio reshaping, including the completion of the Marathon Oil integration and selected asset sales. ConocoPhillips also reported continued advancement on its LNG projects as part of its long term growth...

headline: Is Weaker Q4 Results and 2026 Cash Returns Plan Altering The Investment Case For ConocoPhillips (COP)?
summary: ConocoPhillips recently reported fourth-quarter 2025 results showing revenue of US$14,185 million and net income of US$1,442 million, both down from a year earlier, while reaffirming a first-quarter 2026 ordinary dividend of US$0.84 per share and issuing 2026 production guidance. An interesting angle for investors is that management plans to return 45% of cash from operations to shareholders in 2026 while also targeting more than US$1 billion of run-rate capital and cost reductions by...
